data.title: Top Ten UK Racehorses of All Time / Article Entries
data.meta_description: Top Ten UK Racehorses of All Time
data.text:
The history of UK horse racing is rich with stories of incredible horses whose performances have captivated the nation and set records that have stood the test of time. Here, we celebrate the top ten UK racehorses of all time, whose legacy continues to inspire and awe racing enthusiasts around the world.

1. **Frankel (2008 - Present)**

Arguably the greatest racehorse of all time, Frankel retired undefeated after 14 races, including 10 Group 1 victories. Trained by Sir Henry Cecil and ridden primarily by Tom Queally, Frankel's most memorable performances include his stunning 2000 Guineas win and the Queen Elizabeth II Stakes. His extraordinary speed, stamina, and versatility make him a legend in the racing world.

2. **Arkle (1957 - 1970)**

Arkle is often considered the greatest steeplechaser ever. The Irish-trained gelding dominated National Hunt racing in the 1960s, winning three Cheltenham Gold Cups (1964-1966) and a host of other major races. Known for his incredible jumping ability and stamina, Arkle's legacy is immortalized in both Ireland and the UK.

3. **Red Rum (1965 - 1995)**

Red Rum is a national icon, best known for his unprecedented three Grand National victories in 1973, 1974, and 1977. Trained by Ginger McCain, Red Rum's enduring popularity stems from his remarkable achievements at Aintree and his ability to capture the public's imagination with his tenacity and charisma.

4. **Brigadier Gerard (1968 - 1989)**

Brigadier Gerard is celebrated as one of the greatest milers in history. He won 17 of his 18 races, including the 2000 Guineas, the Queen Elizabeth II Stakes, and the Champion Stakes. Trained by Dick Hern and ridden by Joe Mercer, Brigadier Gerard's versatility and dominant performances across various distances set him apart.

5. **Mill Reef (1968 - 1986)**

Trained by Ian Balding, Mill Reef won 12 of his 14 races, including the Epsom Derby, the Eclipse Stakes, the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes, and the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe. His remarkable speed and ability to perform at the highest level in both the UK and Europe make him one of the all-time greats.

6. **Desert Orchid (1979 - 2006)**

"Desert Orchid," or "Dessie," as he was affectionately known, was a beloved grey steeplechaser who won numerous major races, including the 1989 Cheltenham Gold Cup and four King George VI Chase victories. His versatility across different distances and conditions, combined with his striking appearance and fan following, ensure his place in racing history.

7. **Shergar (1978 - 1983)**

Shergar's brilliance on the track and his tragic kidnapping have made him a legendary figure. Trained by Michael Stoute, Shergar won the Epsom Derby by a record 10 lengths, as well as the Irish Derby and the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes. His dominance and untimely disappearance have cemented his place in racing lore.

8. **Nijinsky (1967 - 1992)**

Nijinsky is best known for being the last horse to win the English Triple Crown (2000 Guineas, Epsom Derby, and St Leger) in 1970. Trained by Vincent O'Brien, Nijinsky also won the Irish Derby and the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes, showcasing his exceptional talent and versatility.

9. **Sea The Stars (2006 - Present)**

Sea The Stars enjoyed a sensational three-year-old campaign in 2009, winning six Group 1 races, including the 2000 Guineas, the Epsom Derby, the Coral-Eclipse, the Juddmonte International, the Irish Champion Stakes, and the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe. Trained by John Oxx and ridden by Mick Kinane, Sea The Stars is celebrated for his consistency, versatility, and remarkable turn of foot.

10. **Phar Lap (1926 - 1932)**

Although primarily raced in Australia, Phar Lap's incredible performances on British soil earn him a place on this list. He won the Agua Caliente Handicap in Mexico, which at the time was the richest race in North America, after winning the 1931 Epsom Handicap in the UK. His dominance in the early 1930s and his tragic death have made him a legendary figure in global horse racing history.
